titleInfo.title: Design sketch of the campus of the Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb.

mods.abstract: A design drawing of the landscape and buildings of the "Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb" by Marr & Holman and Barber & McMurry. Sections of the image are labeled, "Superintendent's residence" in the bottom left, "Dormitory for little boys" in the upper left, "School" in the top center, "Boiler & Laundry Building" in the upper right, and "Two dormitories for girls" in the bottom right. A label reading "Wiles Nashville, Tenn." is on the bottom right corner.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. titleInfo.title: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s School for the Deaf, created by law in 1844, boasts a remarkably long and stable history of educating the state’s students with hearing disabilities. The school has operated since 1845 in Knoxville, closing only for the Civil War and relocating only once (from downtown to an inner suburb). This unit of the Tennessee Virtual Archive features images of this unique institution’s buildings, many of which were designed by noted architect and alumnus Thomas Scott Marr...

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Record has been transformed into MODS 3.5 from a qualified Dublin Core record by the Digital Library of Tennessee, a service hub of the Digital Public Library of America, using a stylesheet available at https://github.com/utkdigitalinitiatives/DLTN.
